snippet: A compromise deal appeared to bring a tentative peace to Southern Weekend’s newsroom, as another Chinese newspaper faced a crisis on Wednesday over the forced publishing of an editorial.
abstract: Propaganda officials in southern Chinese province of Guangdong agree to loosen some controls over embattled newspaper Southern Weekend, whose struggle against censorship has galvanized free-speech activists across country; despite news of compromise deal, paper's weekly edition goes to press late, partly because of internal disputes about content.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
byline.contributor: Edward Wong reported from Guangzhou, and Jonathan Ansfield from Beijing. Mia Li contributed research from Guangzhou, and Shi Da from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: A compromise deal appeared to bring a tentative peace to Southern Weekend’s newsroom, as another Chinese newspaper faced a crisis on Wednesday over the forced publishing of an editorial.

headline.seo: Censored Newspaper in China Returns to Publication Amid Struggles
headline.main: Censored Newspaper Returns to Publication Amid Struggles
headline.print_headline: China Vows to Loosen Controls on a Newspaper
